Basic usage of tekkamaki

Source: vignettes/tekkamaki.Rmd
tekkamaki.Rmd

Run simulation:

library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(tekkamaki)

result = tekka("--seed=42 -y100 -l3") |> print()
#> # A tibble: 1 × 2
#>   sample_family          demography            
#>   <list>                 <list>                
#> 1 <smpl_fml [7,485 × 6]> <spc_tbl_ [4,601 × 5]>

A result is a nested tibble with two columns: sample_family and demography:

sample_family = result$sample_family[[1L]] |> print()
#> # A tibble: 7,485 × 6
#>       id father_id mother_id birth_year location capture_year
#>    <int>     <int>     <int>      <int>    <int>        <int>
#>  1    74         0         0         -4       NA           NA
#>  2    75         0         0         -4       NA           NA
#>  3    73        74        75          1       NA           NA
#>  4    77         0         0         -4       NA           NA
#>  5    78         0         0         -4       NA           NA
#>  6    76        77        78          1       NA           NA
#>  7    72        73        76          8       NA           NA
#>  8    81         0         0         -4       NA           NA
#>  9    82         0         0         -4       NA           NA
#> 10    80        81        82          1       NA           NA
#> # ℹ 7,475 more rows
demography = result$demography[[1L]] |> print()
#> # A tibble: 4,601 × 5
#>     year season location   age count
#>    <dbl>  <dbl>    <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#>  1     0      3        0     4   200
#>  2     1      0        0     0 13457
#>  3     1      3        0     0  1543
#>  4     1      3        2     0  1543
#>  5     2      0        2     1  1543
#>  6     2      3        2     1   248
#>  7     2      3        3     1   253
#>  8     3      0        2     2   248
#>  9     3      0        3     2   253
#> 10     3      3        2     2   175
#> # ℹ 4,591 more rows

Here is an example of visualizing demography:

library(ggplot2)
df = demography |>
  dplyr::mutate(time = year + 0.25 * season) |>
  dplyr::group_by(time, location, age = ifelse(age > 4, "adult", "juvenile")) |>
  dplyr::summarise(count = sum(count))
#> `summarise()` has grouped output by 'time', 'location'. You can override using
#> the `.groups` argument.

ggplot(df) +
  aes(time, count) +
  geom_path(aes(colour = age, group = age)) +
  facet_grid(vars(location)) +
  theme_bw() +
  theme(legend.position = "top")
